admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
The loan for the Bosnia-Herzegovina
            Forestry Improvement Project was approved by the Board on
            June 6, 1985 but never signed. The project is not rated and
            will not be audited. Differences arose between the Bank and
            the Borrower regarding project composition and scope,
            implementation capacity, and availability of local cost
            financing. In terms of scope, the local implementing agency
            proposed at appraisal a project comprising only select
            components which, in the Bank's view, would affect the
            viability of individual investments. In terms of
            implementation capacity, the implementing agency had
            insisted on providing comparable investment packages to all
            local level work organizations despite their technical or
            managerial capacity, while the Bank felt that the project
            should concentrate on organizations with a greater capacity.
            In terms of local cost financing, the implementing agency
            had assured the Bank that local financing would be
            available, but the Borrower indicated that funds were
            sufficient to cover only one third of the local costs. The
            differences were argued throughout the protracted project
            preparation period. This period of over five years saw an
            overall deterioration in Yugoslavia's economy and in
            its relationship with the Bank. After negotiations led to
            some agreements between the Bank and the Borrower in
            December 1985, new laws were enacted in early 1986 on the
            assumption of foreign exchange risk which created
            uncertainty on the part of the project's investors.
            Despite attempts by the bank to find a solution, no response
            was forthcoming and the Bank withdrew the loan offer on July
            31, 1986.
